newsitem.title: MOROCCO: King Hassan sees election behind U.S. Gulf moves.
newsitem.headline: King Hassan sees election behind U.S. Gulf moves.

text.p: King Hassan of Morocco, a staunch ally of Washington, said the latest U.S. moves against Iraq appeared to be influenced by American internal politics, the official MAP news agency reported on Tuesday.

The agency reported the king, who was interviewed by a group of French journalists, as saying "I do not think that the U.S. attitude (against Iraq) was not completely influenced by internal political considerations".
"But I am happy to note that U.S. recently took some steps back...Ourselves and all Arab countries were obliged to protest against the surge of tension in the (Gulf) region," he said.
Presidential elections are due to be held in the United States in November.
Earlier this month, the U.S. fired missiles at Iraq and extended a no-fly zone in southern Iraq after Baghdad sent troops to back a Kurdish faction in the north.
Washington sent reinforcements to the Gulf, including stealth bombers and aircraft carriers, in the ensuing crisis.
Iraq later promised it would no longer fire anti-aircraft missiles at U.S. and allied warplanes patrolling the no-fly zones.

King Hassan said the U.S. was not preparing for a new war against Iraq because "America has no interest in doing it...I do not see what the U.S. will gain...neither Iraq which has nothing to gain from launching hostilities against the U.S.," he said.
U.S. Defence Secretary William Perry has acknowledged that tension is abating and said he might remove one of the two U.S. aircraft carriers from the Gulf next week.
